content.raw: See other comment because I think we don't need some of these methods at all.
content.html: See other comment because I think we don't need some of these methods at all.

content.raw: I think that `worldControlPlugin` shouldn't know anything about the C types declared in `haptix_sim.h`. The interface between this plugin and the C client is communication via protobuf messages. All the conversion functions should only handle Gazebo types and protobuf messages. You should be able to remove all the conversion functions with hxsXXX types.
content.html: I think that worldControlPlugin shouldn't know anything about the C types declared in haptix_sim.h. The interface between this plugin and the C client is communication via protobuf messages. All the conversion functions should only handle Gazebo types and protobuf messages. You should be able to remove all the conversion functions with hxsXXX types.

Can you make a PR to haptix-comm that changes the doxygen in the `include/haptix/comm/haptix_sim.h` header file to be more descriptive, and I can change it here to copy it?

We also need to be aware that HAPTIX users will have no idea what a canonical link is.

Can you make a PR to haptix-comm that changes the doxygen in the include/haptix/comm/haptix_sim.h header file to be more descriptive, and I can change it here to copy it?

We also need to be aware that HAPTIX users will have no idea what a canonical link is.

content.raw:
Everything works as expected. We need to update documentation to specify clearly that

  * `HaptixModelTransformCallback`, `HaptixSetModelTransformCallback` operates on the Model frame, or more specifically the canonical link frame.  While
  * `HaptixAngularVelocityCallback`, `HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback`, `HaptixLinearVelocityCallback`, `HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback` operates on individual link's CG frame.
content.html:
Everything works as expected. We need to update documentation to specify clearly that

  • HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback operates on the Model frame, or more specifically the canonical link frame. While
  • HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback operates on individual link's CG frame.

update.description:
This pull requests adds a plugin that collects information from the Gazebo world and serves responses to Haptix Sim API clients. Two integration tests are included.

* `HaptixWorldPlugin`: A `WorldPlugin` with an ignition-transport node that sets up callbacks for each API call in the [sim API specification](#!/osrf/haptix_api/src/b1b40f00decba895ed62e681e320fccc4e9ee77b/haptix_sim.h?at=default).
* `test/integration/sim_api`: An integration test that verifies the result of each sim API call. It uses `ServerFixture` and creates from scratch any structures that would usually be created by `gzclient`. Thus it's not necessarily a realistic testing situation, but it allows us to easily access and verify server-side state that is manipulated by the API.
* `test/integration/sim_api_client`: An integration test that forks gzclient and gzserver, then runs through every Sim API call and verifies that the return code is OK. This is a coarse-grained test that verifies the typical use case of the Sim API (gzclient, gzserver, and `haptix-comm` client all run in separate processes).
* `arat_test.world`: A test world based on the ARAT world with some extra models, such as a door (needed to test API calls that manipulate joints).

In order to facilitate quick review of this gigantic pull request, we're going to try something new: I will assign several people will review separate components in parallel. If you receive a `HaptixWorldPlugin` callback (`Haptix...Callback`), also review the test for it in `test/integration/sim_api`.

Please let me know if you feel you don't have time to review this PR or if you feel unequipped to do so. We can also move around what's been assigned

This also means that this pull request won't get merged until everyone who's been assigned approves it.

* @caguero: `HaptixAddModelCallback, HaptixRemoveModelCallback`, all of the `HaptixWorldPlugin::Convert...` functions, `HaptixIsLoggingCallback, HaptixStartLoggingCallback, HaptixStopLoggingCallback, HaptixSetModelColorCallback, HaptixModelColorCallback`
* @scpeters: `HaptixModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixSetModelCollideModeCallback, HaptixContactPointsCallback, HaptixModelJointStateCallback`
* @hsu: `HaptixModelTransformCallback, HaptixSetModelTransformCallback, HaptixAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixSetAngularVelocityCallback, HaptixLinearVelocityCallback, HaptixSetLinearVelocityCallback`, `OnUserCameraPose, HaptixSimInfoCallback
* @gerkey: `HaptixResetCallback, HaptixApplyWrenchCallback, HaptixApplyTorqueCallback, HaptixApplyForceCallback, OnWorldUpdate`, HaptixCameraTransformCallback, HaptixSetCameraTransformCallback
* @\_jrivero\_: Lines 0-278 (includes, destructor, load) of `HaptixWorldPlugin`, `sim_api_client` test, CMake files affected by this commit, HaptixModelGravityCallback, HaptixSetModelGravityCallback`
update.title: HAPTIX Sim API implementation

content.raw: Yeah, I know. I was considering using ID as a performance optimization but it never panned out. I'm fine with deleting it; it's easier to remove stuff now than to add it in (like what we did with `set_model_link_state`). Want to make a PR to haptix-comm?
content.html: Yeah, I know. I was considering using ID as a performance optimization but it never panned out. I'm fine with deleting it; it's easier to remove stuff now than to add it in (like what we did with set_model_link_state). Want to make a PR to haptix-comm?

content.raw: You could initialize `_result` to `false` here and avoid to set `_result = false` in each error situation. Don't forget to set `_result = true` at the end of the function. This applies to all the callbacks that have multiple error checks.
content.html: You could initialize _result to false here and avoid to set _result = false in each error situation. Don't forget to set _result = true at the end of the function. This applies to all the callbacks that have multiple error checks.

content.raw: I know we talked about this before but I feel that we should completely remove `id` from the HAPTIX API. We're including an ID in hxsModel but there's nothing to do with that ID in the HAPTIX API.
content.html: I know we talked about this before but I feel that we should completely remove id from the HAPTIX API. We're including an ID in hxsModel but there's nothing to do with that ID in the HAPTIX API.

content.raw:
Another idea: You could replace your `for` loop with two steps:

* `std::remove_if()` with a lambda function where you check if it's time to remove the impulse from `this->wrenchDurations` (the condition of your `if` right now).
* Apply the force/torque through all the elements of `this->wrenchDurations`.

Ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erase%E2%80%93remove_idiom
content.html:
Another idea: You could replace your for loop with two steps:

  • std::remove_if() with a lambda function where you check if it's time to remove the impulse from this->wrenchDurations (the condition of your if right now).
  • Apply the force/torque through all the elements of this->wrenchDurations.

Ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erase%E2%80%93remove_idiom

content.raw:
The test case I used was the MultipleForces test case in the sim_api test. It adds 6 identical forces, three with a duration of 1 second and three with a duration of 2 seconds. The behavior of wrenchDurations should thus be: push 6 forces onto the stack, erase 3 forces 1 second later, erase 3 more forces 2 seconds later. The test verifies that it receives the correct forces for the next 3 seconds (full force, half force, then no force).

I didn't see any difference between assigning the iter to the return value of `erase` vs. not. I think this is because when `erase` is called, the vector container moves all the elements up to fill the place of the erased item, and when `erase` is called on the last element, the for loop exits before we dereference the vector `end`.

Still, I'll change it to be safe.
	
5c2902b
 
4212418
content.html:
The test case I used was the MultipleForces test case in the sim_api test. It adds 6 identical forces, three with a duration of 1 second and three with a duration of 2 seconds. The behavior of wrenchDurations should thus be: push 6 forces onto the stack, erase 3 forces 1 second later, erase 3 more forces 2 seconds later. The test verifies that it receives the correct forces for the next 3 seconds (full force, half force, then no force).

I didn't see any difference between assigning the iter to the return value of erase vs. not. I think this is because when erase is called, the vector container moves all the elements up to fill the place of the erased item, and when erase is called on the last element, the for loop exits before we dereference the vector end.

Still, I'll change it to be safe.

5c2902b

4212418
